subject: Marketing
title: Loss Framing vs Gain Framing
description: A short lesson to help you apply Loss Framing vs Gain Framing.

hook.text: Losing $20 feels twice as painful as finding $20 feels good. Losses loom larger.

buildup.text: Kahneman and Tversky proved loss aversion is one of the strongest forces in decision-making.

discovery.text: Framing a price as avoiding a loss is more persuasive than framing it as gaining value.

twist.text: 'Save $200' outsells 'Get $200 worth of features' even though the math is identical.

climax.text: Loss framing taps primal fear. Gain framing appeals to optimismâ€”fear usually wins.

punchline.text: People work harder to avoid loss than to gain.

quiz.question: Why is loss framing more effective than gain framing in pricing?
options: Losses feel psychologically twice as painful as equivalent gains
Loss framing is cheaper to implement
